articles.title: THE MONTHLY BULLETIN OF SAN JOSE AMATEUR ASTRONOMERS, INC.
articles.summary: This document is the February 1970 monthly bulletin for the San Jose Amateur Astronomers, Inc. It lists the key contact information for the organization, including the President (Trudy Bell), Vice President (Dave Erikson), and Bulletin Editor (Clayton Neece).

articles.title: REGULAR S.J.A.A. MEETING
articles.summary: The Regular S.J.A.A. Meeting is scheduled for Friday, February 6th, at 8:00 p.m. at the Leninger Community Center. The agenda includes a talk by Dr. Larry Caroff from Ames, Moffet Field, on the Quasi-Stellar object PHL-5200, which exhibits a notable absorption envelope. Additionally, members will vote on an irrevocable clause that, if passed, would grant the club tax exemptions, and full member attendance is requested for this important decision.

articles.title: BOARD MEETING
articles.summary: The document serves as an announcement for an upcoming board meeting for board members. The meeting is scheduled for Friday, February 13th, starting at 8:00 p.m. at Clayton Neece's home located at 1650 Calado Ct. in Campbell. Members unable to attend are asked to contact Dave Erikson.

articles.title: STAR PARTY
articles.summary:
## STAR PARTY

Because of the moon's position, there will be no star party for the month of February.

=== PAGE 2 ===

articles.title: GENERAL INFORMATION:
articles.summary: The article announces information regarding a March solar eclipse and planned trips to Mexico, available through Mr. Weslee Kendall. It also details significant progress on the club's observatory, including the completion of the pier and ground leveling, and the construction of a mounting for a 12.5-inch reflector. Additionally, the bulletin includes a member name correction and classified advertisements for various astronomical equipment.

articles.title: WAA REPORT
articles.summary: The Western Amateur Astronomers (WAA) held their annual business meeting on January 17, 1970, in Fresno, California, where they discussed the closure dispute of the Lick Observatory public observing program and planned upcoming events. The meeting outlined details for the 1970 convention in Sacramento, announced two smaller conferences in April (Telescope Makers Conference and Bay Area Astronomical Meeting), and discussed future conventions in Hawaii and Riverside. Additionally, WAA gauged member interest in a group purchase of lower-cost mica solar filters.

articles.title: IN THE RIGHT PLACE AT THE WRONG TIME
articles.summary: This article compiles a series of humorous science-themed puns, jokes, and anecdotes, many stemming from astronomical conventions. It showcases wordplay on concepts from statistical mechanics, physics, chemistry, optics, and geology, maintaining a lighthearted and comedic tone throughout.
